intro: Astragalus cruciatus var. elongatus, commonly known as the long-stemmed milkvetch, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of North America. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender stems that are often branched and covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, yellow flowers arranged in dense spikes, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are compound, consisting of several pairs of oval to lance-shaped leaflets. This variety is valued for its ecological role in stabilizing soils and providing forage for wildlife.
